            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="pp_main_richtext_1" class="remove-bottom-space A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL"></p><p>To be eligible for HSBC Electric Vehicle Personal Instalment Loan, you must:</p>
<div class="commonMark-list">
<ul role="list">
<li>be a Hong Kong resident</li>
<li>be at least 18 years old</li>
<li>have a monthly income of at least HKD5,000</li>
<li>not have other car loan applications for the electric vehicle and you haven't paid for the vehicle in full</li>
</ul>
</div>
<p>In addition to the general documents required to process a loan application, other documents you'll need to provide:</p>
<div class="commonMark-list">
<ul role="list">
<li>Prior to loan drawdown, provide past 6 months' proof of the order agreement or documents showing the payment of deposits for the purchase of eligible electric vehicle<sup><a href="#fn-loans-evpurchaseproof" data-back-link-connected=""><span aria-hidden="true">3</span><span class="visuallyhidden">Footnote link 3</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Within 6 months after loan drawdown, provide vehicle registration document or related documents as proof of electric vehicle ownership<sup><a href="#fn-loans-evownership" data-back-link-connected=""><span aria-hidden="true">4</span><span class="visuallyhidden">Footnote link 4</span></a></sup></li>
</ul>
</div>
<p></p>
</div></div>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="pp_main_richtext_6" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">That depends on two key factors: how much you need to borrow, and how much you can afford to repay.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">It's best to borrow only what you actually need and resist the temptation of borrowing extra money. Remember, your loan does not have to be for a round figure! You can usually borrow the exact amount you need.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">It's also wise to look at all your other expenses while working out how much you can afford to repay. Try not to spend more than 30% of your gross monthly income on all your loan repayments, with the possible exception of mortgage repayments which may be up to 50% of your income. That way, you can better ensure that you can afford the extra cost of loan repayments without worrying that you can't meet other financial commitments.</p>

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="pp_main_richtext_7" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">A good general rule is to avoid borrowing for longer than the life of what you're paying for. For example, if you have an annual expense such as a tax bill, aim for a loan of 12 months of less. Otherwise, you'll still be paying off your first loan when the next year's tax demand arrives.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">By budgeting carefully, you can balance the loan amount, loan period, and amount you can afford to repay each month.</p>

            <span class="chevron"></span>

        <section id="-149479783__panel0" class="exp-content" aria-hidden="true" tabindex="-1">

            <div class="M-CONTMAST-RW-RBWM O-SMARTSPCGEN-DEV rich-text" role="region"><div id="pp_main_richtext_9" class=" A-PAR16R-RW-ALL-WRAPPER" data-date-format="D/M/YYYY" data-time-format="HH:MM:SS A" data-zone="Hongkong">
    <p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">Generally, the earlier you make your loan repayment, the more you'll save on outstanding interest payments. But you should consider early repayment charges before you decide whether or not to pay off your loans early.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">We use the 'Rule of 78' (also known as the 'straight-line method') to calculate the interest and principal proportion in each monthly repayment. While your monthly repayment amount remains the same throughout the loan tenor, more interest will generally be included in earlier repayments than principal. That means the amount of outstanding interest is likely to be small if you've been making repayments as scheduled for some time.</p> 
<p class="A-PAR16R-RW-ALL">If you choose to pay off the loan early, you may lose more than you gain because the amount of interest saved may not be enough to cover any charges for an early repayment. If you're considering an early repayment, you can contact us to check the total amount you'll need to pay, including the outstanding loan balance, early repayment charges and other fees, and outstanding interest. This way, you can compare and make an informed decision on whether to go ahead with the early repayment.</p>
</div></div>
